Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Story: I was sweeping up hair clippings when my phone buzzed with a message from my stepdad: “Rough day. Can we talk later?” I felt that familiar tug in my chest—the one that always comes when he reaches out. I know he counts on me to check in, to ask if he and Mom are okay, to be the glue that keeps our patched-together family from falling apart. But just as I typed a quick reply, the bell above the salon door jingled. A woman stepped in, clutching her purse, eyes darting nervously. I recognized the look; she was new, probably anxious about trusting a stranger with her hair. My boss always says, “First impressions matter—make them feel at home.” I could see her scanning the room, waiting for someone to greet her, to offer a smile and a seat. My phone vibrated again in my pocket, but I couldn’t ignore the client. My heart pounded as I stood there, torn between the urge to comfort my stepdad and the duty to welcome this woman, both expecting me to be present, to care, to make things better.
